awd_abstract_narration:
The project will advance three crucial themes on markets for targeted advertising and consumer privacy. The first will address whether consumers benefit or are harmed when a firm they do business with can sell their data on to other firms they might deal with. It will study whether giving individuals the right to opt out of such data sales is an effective means of protecting consumer interests. The second theme will study the consequences of giving consumers ownership over their own data with the right to sell it themselves, if they choose. The third theme will study whether the increasing precision of targeted advertising leads to excessively specialized choices for consumers in media markets supported by advertising.  Regulators including the US Congress and the European Union (with the adoption of the General Data Privacy Regulation) have underscored the urgent need to understand these issues to draft appropriate policies to protect consumers and their data without stifling innovative business practices. The project will provide guidance on the merits of policies that restrict targeting, give consumers opt-out rights, and give consumers the right to sell their own data. 
 
The project will be primarily theoretical in its methodology, although the themes are inspired from actual current (and expanding) practices and policy debates. The first part will innovate a joint equilibrium analysis of the market where data is harvested and the market where it is deployed. The analysis will begin with a monopoly information-harvesting firm collecting data from its market to sell it on to firms in a second market. While the first firm will want to render its market attractive to consumers (through low prices, say), consumers are wary about participating, for they will rationally anticipate that their data might be used against them (in the form of high prices, say) in the secondary market. Data-sharing may benefit consumers because markets where data are used operate more efficiently and consumers can command part of this gain by exacting discounts in the first market. Perversely, letting individual consumers choose whether to opt out of data sharing may hurt them collectively, as consumers with "something to hide" are penalized with higher prices. This is a stepping stone for analyzing competition in data collection and how data harvesters parcel out data for sale. The second part will examine who should be able to sell consumer data. It will compare when firms collect and sell on the data with when consumers can sell their own data. When data are used to craft discount offers, consumers may engineer greater discount competition by pricing their data below the cost of lost privacy. Individuals eager to be targeted might inflict negative externalities on others who are revealed to have strong product preferences and may face higher prices. Equilibrium consequences of consumer pricing have not been previously addressed and are quite intricate. Furthermore, firms should anticipate that consumers may strategically manipulate the information they sell on. This analysis will be a springboard for studying how savvy consumers will make the most of their data by selectively curating what they sell into one or more digital personas. The third part will draw on different modeling approaches of product differentiation and will meld these to an advertising-financed business model of media economics. Advertisers and content consumers (who are prospective consumers of the advertised goods) constitute the two sides of the market, and they are intermediated by media platforms which choose advertising prices (and consumer subscription fees when relevant). Competing platforms connect advertisers with viewers: a platform's content is most appealing to viewers with "nearby" tastes, and the bundle of viewers at a platform is most attractive to "nearby" advertisers. Before internet-enabled tracking and targeting, bucketing of advertisers to consumers was crudely enabled through specialized media content. Now that individuals are tracked and targeted, market performance might be enhanced through better matching but worsened through too many platforms. Advertisers with broad appeal may crowd out narrow ones under the old business model, and foster insufficiently few specialized, but the new business model may go too far in the other direction. These topics have not been broached in media economics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Under support from this grant, the investigators developed economic models to better understand how consumer data is used in markets, with the goal of informing the policy debate about how and whether that data should be gathered, who should have the right to say how it is used, and how best to safeguard consumer privacy. The findings from this work were publicized to other economists through journal articles and to public and private-sector policymakers through conferences. The project also provided mentoring to graduate students by helping them hone their research skills as research assistants and by providing support for their own research projects on themes related to consumer privacy.

Consumer data privacy is on lawmakers’ minds: the European Union introduced its sweeping General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in 2018, 15 US states have passed data privacy laws, and the US Congress may soon enact the American Privacy Rights Act (APRA). Our project analyzed the implications of one of the key planks in APRA: giving consumers the right to opt out of targeted advertising. Our main finding was that the right to opt out usually benefits consumers for two reasons. One of these reasons is straightforward: some consumers may value privacy for its own sake more highly than the potential cost savings from a targeted discount. Giving these consumers the choice to opt out makes them better off. The second reason is more subtle: by opting out of targeted discounts, the privacy-conscious encourage firms to compete more vigorously with their list prices, and this leads to more affordable prices for all consumers, both those who opted out and those who did not.

A closely related issue is whether websites should seek consent from visitors before selling information about their visit on to retail firms. Often, opting out of such tracking is possible but involves a nuisance cost for the consumer; an alternative would be to forbid tracking unless visitors actively opt in. If the nuisance cost is very small, one might imagine there would be little difference between these policies, since they both give the consumer choice. However, our work under this grant showed that small nuisance costs can have large effects on both privacy outcomes and retail prices, and so active opt-in could be a much better policy for consumers. Loosely, this is because going to even a small effort to opt out reveals that a consumer has something to hide from the retailer (namely, that she would have paid more than its current price), and this causes the prices for opt-out consumers to drift higher and higher.

These examples of consumer choice are part of a broader movement toward giving individuals full “property rights” over their own data. If this happens, individuals will become the curators of their own digital identities by deciding what information they release, and to whom. Under this grant, we studied how much information individual consumers should disclose to a monopolist firm. We showed that by carefully choosing which facts to disclose and which to withhold, consumers can organize themselves into “buying groups” that ensure that everyone is served, everyone pays less than they would have done otherwise, and all of the gains from the disclosed information are captured by consumers, not the monopolist.

The grant supported several graduate students, including Dennis J. Cambell. Campbell’s PhD dissertation “An empirical analysis of a two-sided, ad-financed media platform with targeted advertising” was successfully defended at the University of Virginia in April 2023. His work focuses on advertisers which target different user demographics while users are found to view ads as a nuisance. The platform (Facebook) sets ad levels to get the greatest return from connecting the two sides of the market with targeted ads. He created his own dataset by surveying a representative sample of 2287 US Facebook users. He uses structural econometric techniques to estimate advertising returns to different demographics. These vary quite widely. He engages his estimates for a counterfactual analysis in which Facebook is no longer permitted to target ads across consumers. Even though the predicted ad price falls, advertisers earn less when barred from targeting ads. Facebook’s profits fall while users are worse off because of the higher ad levels set.

The findings from the grant contribute to economics by delivering new insights on a central topic in the field: market interactions between consumers and firms. These findings have been (and will continue to be) publicized to the scientific community through journal articles and conferences. Furthermore, the findings have a broader impact on an important and timely public policy issue, the appropriate regulation of consumer data and privacy. Our findings provide concrete recommendations to policymakers about how to ensure that individuals can be protected, and can even benefit, in a world of big data.
